raw_text:
'Last chance' warning for voters
 
 People in England, Scotland and Wales must have registered by 1700 GMT to be able to vote in the general election if it is held, as expected, on 5 May.
 
 Those who filled in forms last autumn should already be on the register - but those who have moved house or were on holiday may have been left off. There will also be elections for local councils and mayors in parts of England on 5 May. The deadline for voters to register in Northern Ireland expired on Thursday.
 
 Completed registration forms can be handed into local authorities throughout the day on Friday, and some will accept them by fax. As well as for English county councils, polls for unitary authorities at Bristol, Isle of Wight and Stockton-on-Tees and mayors at Doncaster, Hartlepool, North Tyneside and Stoke-on-Trent are also scheduled for 5 May. Last week Preston City Council reported that more than 14,000 of its voters were not registered. Its electoral roll fell by 17.5% in a year - the biggest dip in the UK. An Electoral Commission spokeswoman said: "Political decisions are made on your behalf every day but only by using your right to vote at an election can you really have a say on the issues you care about. "If you want your voice to be heard on 5 May you will need to have registered by Friday 11 March." Council tax payers are not eligible to vote without registration, officials have stressed.
llama3.2:1b: People in England, Scotland, and Wales must register to vote by the deadline of 1700 GMT on 5 May for a general election. Completed registration forms can be handed in throughout the day, including by fax, while those registered last autumn are already eligible to vote but may need to update their information.
llama3.2:3b: People in England, Scotland and Wales must register by 1700 GMT on Friday for the expected general election on 5 May, with local council elections also taking place. Those who filled in forms last autumn may be missing from the register if they moved or were holidaying. Completed registration forms can be handed in by Friday, with some accepting them by fax.
gemma2:2b: Voters in England, Scotland and Wales must register to vote in the general election on May 5th. Registration deadline is 1700 GMT on Friday, March 11th.  Local council and mayor elections will also be held on May 5th in parts of England. Northern Ireland registration has expired.  Forms can be submitted in person or by fax on Friday.
qwen2.5:0.5b: English, Scottish and Welsh voters must register in advance before 5 May 2017 for the general election; those who completed their forms last autumn should already be on the list, but those who moved or were away may have been left off. Voters can fill out registration forms at local authorities throughout the day of Friday and some will accept them by fax. The deadline for voters to register in Northern Ireland is due on Thursday. Preston City Council reported that around 14,000 of its voters did not register before the election. It is illegal for political decisions to be made without voting. Voters need to have registered by the specified date.
qwen2.5:1.5b: People in England, Scotland, and Wales must register before April 29 for the upcoming general election on May 5th; those who moved or were absent may need to re-register; there will be elections for local councils and mayors across Northern Ireland on that day as well; polls are also scheduled for some English unitary authorities and mayors in certain cities.
qwen2.5:3b: People in England, Scotland and Wales must register by 1700 GMT on 11 March to vote in the general election expected for 5 May. Those who need to update their addresses or were away should check the electoral roll. Local elections are also scheduled for the same date. Registration forms can be submitted throughout Friday via local authorities or fax. The 5 May poll includes English county councils, unitary authorities and mayors' elections in several places. Electoral Commission states only registered voters have a say on political decisions. Unregistered individuals should register by 11 March to vote; council tax payers are ineligible without registration.
opencoder:1.5b:
Last chance warning for voters

People in England, Scotland and Wales must register by 17:00 GMT to cast their votes if the election is held on 5 May.

Registered voters who filled out the registration forms last summer should already be registered - but those who moved or were on holiday may have been excluded. Local elections also include regional councils and mayors in parts of England scheduled for 5 May. The deadline for voting in Northern Ireland expired on Thursday.

The registration process can be completed by mail on Friday, and some voters will accept their registrations by post. Registration forms are accepted for county governments at a later date. Also, polling stations at Bristol, Isle of Wight and Stockton-on-Tees and mayors at Doncaster, Hartlepool, North Tyneside and Stoke-on-Trent are scheduled for 5 May.

Last week Preston City Council reported that more than 14,000 of its voters were not registered. The electoral roll fell by up to 17.5% in a year - the largest drop in the UK.

The decision process is carried out on a day's notice but only with your right to vote. If you want your voice heard on 5 May, you will need to register last Sunday morning.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details:

1. The last chance warning for voters in England, Scotland, and Wales is that they must register before the general election on 5 May if it is held.
2. Those who filled out forms last autumn should already be on the register - but those who have moved house or were on holiday may have been left off. There will also be elections for local councils and mayors in parts of England on 5 May. The deadline for voters to register in Northern Ireland expired on Thursday.
3. Completed registration forms can be handed into local authorities throughout the day on Friday, and some will accept them by fax. As well as for English county councils, polls for unitary authorities at Bristol, Isle of Wight and Stockton-on-Tees and mayors at Doncaster, Hartlepool, North Tyneside and Stoke-on-Trent are also scheduled for 5 May. Last week Preston City Council reported that more than 14,000 of its voters were not registered. Its electoral roll fell by 17.5% in a year - the biggest dip in the UK. An Electoral Commission spokeswoman said: "Political decisions are made on your behalf every day but only by using your right to vote at an election can you really have a say on the issues you care about." If you want your voice to be heard on 5 May you will need to have registered by Friday 11 March. Council tax payers are not eligible to vote without registration, officials have stressed.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text into a concise summary. Let me read through it carefully.

The first part says that people in England, Scotland, and Wales must register by 1700 GMT on May 5 to vote in the general election. That's an important deadline because they can't vote otherwise if there are any changes. It mentions that some people moved away or had holidays, so their registration was left off.

Then it talks about local elections for councils and mayors happening on May 5. Northern Ireland has its ballot roll expiration on Thursday. Completed forms should be handed in at the same day, but some might take a different route through fax or mail.

Also, for England's county councils, polls are scheduled for May 5. Additionally, there are polling activities planned for unitary authorities in parts of the UK and mayors from specific towns. Preston City Council had the highest issue with their voting register dropping by 17.5%, which is a big drop compared to others.

They also mentioned that some council taxes aren't eligible unless registered on May 11, March. So the key points are registration deadlines, voter participation issues in Northern Ireland, and local elections in England and the UK.

I need to make sure I include all these main points while keeping it concise. Let me try structuring the summary around each of these aspects without going into too much detail.
</think>

People in England, Scotland, and Wales must register by 1700 GMT on May 5 to vote in the general election. Those who moved or were holiday leaves may not have registered. Local councils and mayors will be elected on May 5. Northern Ireland's ballot roll expired on Thursday. Completed forms can be handed in throughout the day, with some using fax. For England, completed forms will also be accepted at local authorities, and polling events are scheduled for parts of the UK and mayors in specific towns. Preston City Council had a significant drop in its voting register, and council taxes aren't eligible without registration until May 11.
tinyllama:1.1b: In England, Scotland and Wales, people who did not register before a specified deadline must be able to vote in the general election if it is held on May 5. Those who had moved or were on holiday but had been left off their registration forms will also need to cast a ballot. Complete registration forms are accepted by postal service from local authorities throughout the day, while some poll dates for unitary authorities and mayoral elections are scheduled for May 5 in England alone. The Preston City Council reported a fall of 17.5% in the electoral roll for its area, leading to the speaker for Electoral Commission stating that "Political decisions are made on your behalf every day but only by using your right to vote at an election can you really have a say on the issues you care about." Vote-by-mail options will not be available to those who did not register or have moved.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The general election is scheduled for May 5 in England and Wales, with elections for local councils and mayors also taking place across Northern Ireland on that day. To register to vote in time, people should be registered by 1700 GMT at the latest. Some parts of England may have additional registration deadlines due to holidays or changes in their voting locations. Voters in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland must register before they are eligible to cast a ballot. The deadline for voters to register varies by region and can be found on the Electoral Commission's website.
phi:2.7b: Voters in England, Scotland and Wales must register by 17030 GMT to vote in the expected general election on 5 May. Completing registration forms is crucial as it affects voter turnout for local councils and mayors' elections on 5 May, which also falls under the deadline. Failure to register can cause a significant decrease in the electoral roll for certain areas like Preston City Council, with its voter count dropping by 17.5% in just one year. The Electoral Commission has emphasized that political decisions are made daily based on voters' preferences, and not registering can mean missing out on having a say in issues that matter to them.
orca-mini:3b: The UK general election is scheduled for 5 May and people in England, Scotland, and Wales must register by 1700 GMT on 11 March to be able to vote in the election. If you want your voice to be heard on 5 May, you must have registered by this date. However, those who moved house or were on holiday may have been left off the electoral roll. The deadline for voters in Northern Ireland to register has already passed and completed registration forms can be handed into local authorities throughout the day on Friday. Some councils accept completed forms by fax. The Preston City Council's electoral roll fell by 17.5% in a year - the biggest dip in the UK. You must have registered by Friday 11 March to vote in the general election.
hermes3:3b: Register by 1700 GMT on Fri to vote in UK general election on May 5th. Unregistered people who moved or were away may be missed from voter roll.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The last chance for voters in England, Scotland, and Wales to register for the general election held on May 5 is by 4 PM GMT on March 11. Those who filled out forms during the autumn register may be left off if they've moved or were absent during registration deadlines. Completed registration forms can be handed in at local authorities or some will accept fax submissions. Last week, Preston City Council reported over 14,000 voters without registrations, and the electoral roll declined by 17.5% in a year. Political decisions impact individuals on a daily basis, but voting is crucial for having a say on desired issues. Non-registered council tax payers are not eligible to vote.
chatgpt-4o-latest: People in England, Scotland, and Wales must register by 1700 GMT to vote in the expected 5 May general election. Those who moved or were on holiday may not be on the register. Local council and mayoral elections will also take place in parts of England. The registration deadline for Northern Ireland has already passed. Forms can be submitted to local authorities, some accepting faxed copies. Preston City Council reported a significant drop in registered voters. The Electoral Commission urged people to register by 11 March to have a say in political decisions, emphasizing that council tax payment alone does not grant voting rights.
stablelm2:1.6b: People in England, Scotland, and Wales need to register by a certain date (May 5th) if they want to vote in the upcoming general election or local council elections taking place on that day. Those who moved recently or were on vacation may not be registered. Registration forms can be submitted through local authorities until Friday, with some accepting faxed documents and electronic submissions as well. County councils polls for unitary authorities at five locations will also take place on May 5th. In the past year, the number of unregistered voters in Preston City Council dropped by 5%.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Voters in England, Scotland, and Wales must register by midnight GMT on Friday, March 11, for the general election scheduled for May 5. Those who moved or were away during last autumn's forms-filling period might still be unregistered. In Northern Ireland, the registration deadline was Thursday. Unregistered voters can register at local authorities by Friday, with some accepting submissions via fax. The election includes contests for English county councils and mayors in Bristol, Isle of Wight, Stockton-on-Tees, Doncaster, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, and Stoke-on-Trent, along with unitary authorities at these locations. Preston City Council reported over 14,000 unregistered voters, a 17.5% decrease from the previous year. Registration is crucial for wielding influence on issues, as council tax payers alone cannot vote without it.
reference: There will also be elections for local councils and mayors in parts of England on 5 May.People in England, Scotland and Wales must have registered by 1700 GMT to be able to vote in the general election if it is held, as expected, on 5 May.Last week Preston City Council reported that more than 14,000 of its voters were not registered."If you want your voice to be heard on 5 May you will need to have registered by Friday 11 March."Those who filled in forms last autumn should already be on the register - but those who have moved house or were on holiday may have been left off.
